utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Dagen McDowell, Jessica Tarlov, Lawrence Jones, and Greg Gutfeld. It's five o'clock in New York City, and this is THE FIVE. It's crime and no punishment in America's biggest city as violent spikes all across the country. Remember how New York City was rocked by looting last summer while a new report says prosecutors are dropping charges for hundreds of people who were arrested. D.A.'s are reportedly blaming a lack of evidence and COVID-related court delays for why they didn't prosecute. The New York Post summing up the situation this way, let them loot. And more brazen crimes caught on camera police naming a suspect in this horrific video showing a man getting shot after falling into two children on the sidewalk. Luckily no one was killed. And out in Chicago during a Puerto Rican pride parade celebration a 24 - year-old man was shot in the head at point-blank range and a woman in his car was shot in the neck. At last report she was in critical condition and the man died. Former police chief James Craig blaming the crisis on the lack of common sense.

utterances.speaker: GRAIG
utterances.utterance: Well, I've got to -- let me just start by saying that our profession is in crisis right now. And when you talk about issues like bail reform, the courts are not using common sense, they are putting these violent criminals back in our communities, and so that's the common thread we see in all of our cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, I know that you were out and about covering the George Floyd protest last year and a lot of -- and all across America, not just in New York there was looting, but here in New York apparently if you did it, you're likely to be able to get off scotch free.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: It's sad. One of my first jobs is working in the juvenile justice department and I wanted to help these young people get off the street and make sure that they didn't go into the court system. But the judge was very strict. So, they always say, Lawrence, you there as a resource to give them programs but I've got to give them consequences or it's just going to be the same thing over and over again. This is how we train our children to know that there's consequences for their actions. But what we have right now with the Democrats is an ideology. They don't believe people should be behind bars. And I've been in the criminal justice reform movement for a minute. I don't know when they decided to shift this narrative. It used to be equal justice under law. Getting some of these disparities out of way whether it's over policing or if there was targeting in some cases. That is no longer the mission. These D.A.'s have a mission and they believe that people should be back on the street. Our jail system was created for people that are at risk to society, and they don't believe that to be the case. They believe everyone can be reformed. What we've seen in these big cities is repeat offenders. We know who these people are. So, I guess my message to the left is, when is enough, enough? You know what's going to happen, eventually people are going to get fed up and Democrats and Republicans are going to have people in there that are going to be strong-armed, and then it's going to swing all the far to the right and Democrats are going to be really mad, but that's going to come when people get fed up with their conditions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Where do the business owners go to get their justice?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, definitely not from the media and not from the Democrats. Look, it used to be that crime like represent -- reflected every day existence like, you know, there will be a random theft here or a fight in the bar over a girl. Today it reflects a rancid neglected environment. Right? It's like where mad man roamed the streets and people get attacked with ice picks. It's like every -- you hear a new weapon that happens to one of Eric Adams volunteers, but this happens and because the left, and what's coming out of academia, are reinterpreting actual cartel assistance as oppression. So when Andrew Yang at the debate says look, we really need to get these folks off the street, into the hospitals because they're hurting themselves and they're hurting others, you get some idiot like Michelle Goldberg at the New York Times who claims that that's somehow selfish and that it's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- like alienating. You can't two thoughts in your head. You want to help the homeless, you also want to help the citizens. So the real obstacle is that the media who portrays concern for families and businesses as a lack of compassion. In a sense, they are weaponizing compassion to stifle speech, and then that reflects -- I mean, what that reflex allows for is no adult solution. Right? There is no response, the only way forward is down. So, I wrote my notes I have three -- this is four reasons. One, the abandonment of its sentence, we talked about that, prison and bail were incentives to keep your nose clean. The twisted liberal view that somehow, it's a moral right to leave a distractive mentally deranged life on the streets, but then you have, finally, the woke distraction. Mayors and governors and bureaucracy get by with this criminal neglect by waiving the right flag, by celebrating the right holiday, by using the right pronoun, by supporting the right parades, somehow, that deflects from there just degradation of the cities that they run.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You said -- can I - I'm sorry, I'll get you in one second. But you said something I thought was so interesting. I wonder if you could expand on it just a little bit or maybe say it again so that it sinks in to me. It's so interesting. The weaponization of compassion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's been going on. We talk about families who are asking like, please help us, we know that this, the red flag laws, all of these things, and that doesn't ever seem to help them and then you have more crime.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Exactly. If you -- if you say, if we reduce crime, and that somehow sides with Republicans, you aren't compassionate. You aren't compassionate. So, what ends up happening is that eliminates even the Democrats from coming up with a solution.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're not allowed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because you're not allowed to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's really interesting. I want you listen to -- actually we'll go to Jessica, this is the Atlanta mayor, she has thoughts as to why this is all happening. Take a look here.

utterances.speaker: MAYOR KEISHA LANCE BOTTOMS (D-GA)
utterances.utterance: Well, I think there are a couple of things that you have to compare. Remember in Georgia, we were opened up before the rest of the country, even before the CDC said that it was a for us to open. So our night clubs and our bars remain open. We have people traveling here from across the country to party in our city.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jessica, is that the reason? Crime is up and it's happening all across the country?

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Certainly not at the level of the spikes. And Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez posited something similar a few months ago talking about this is because people are hungry. Right? Like they need bread. People taking Nikes, it's not like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're not exactly --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- they want a brad instead. Obviously, as someone who is a member of the Democratic Party, I don't agree with the hot take that we're pro- crime and that we don't care about anything. But what I will say to the points that were made earlier about they are becoming a pro law and order Democratic constituency, that is what has - and we'll see what happens tomorrow when it's the last day, it's the primary day for the mayoral race. But that's what propelled Eric Adams to the top of the pack there and he didn't even get the endorsement actually at the police union. Andrew Yang did get that. But his background in law enforcement as a New York City police chief captain and even looking at Val Demings, someone who is the first black females police chief in Orlando, and listening to them talk about how we can address these issues, there is a hell of a lot of compassion in there, but there are also smart solutions and things that a vast of Americans agree with. We all at this table know reform is needed. Right. That's across-the-board and every one of the cities certainly so that we don't end up with another George Floyd situation.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think the problem is, Jessica, Democrats are in charge right now. They can do -- they can implement policies to protect people, and I find it troubling that Democrats aren't particularly upset that the people that looted, that distracted from a movement that was supposed to be for justice, are upset. These people distort their movement.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I totally understand that point and I lived in the high looting neighborhood, it was scary. And I was one who participated in the protest as well, obviously peacefully. But we did have a lot of problems under Rudy Giuliani who was a Republican mayor here who has, you know, his police chief had to say, actually we went too far with a lot of these tactics and so we need to strike the right balance in this. And I think that that requires a bipartisan --

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: How about locking up perpetrators and siding with the businessowners wo have had their livelihoods destroyed in low-income minority areas? How about siding with the people who are getting punched in the face by assailants who should not be in the street?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Who over and over again have been arrested dozens of times. Somebody's nose gets broken, the perpetrator gets a desk appearance ticket and then he's right back on the streets and he's attacking elderly Asian woman. The Democrats and liberals, part of the problem is that they are cherry picking the lawlessness that outrages them. Last summer, mostly peaceful, don't worry about those businesses that are being burned down, but then the Capitol Hill riots the world is coming to an end. And then like now, that metropolitan mayhem, the police are the problem or the Republicans or Donald Trump if you're listening to James Ghulam (Ph) Carville. Democrats think that some crime is OK and they think that some crime is not OK. And if you look at the capitol, right after the Capitol Hill riots Republicans came out loudly forcefully and genuinely condemn that violence. And the people are being prosecuted. Its 480 defendants so far, up to 550 people will be prosecuted by the attorney general and by the Justice Department and unprecedented in scale case according to the attorney general. But in the meantime, you have Cynthia -- somebody like Cynthia Nixon who ran for governor who is a left-wing socialist and it's what Lawrence was talking about, she is talking about, she is mad that the CVC on her corner is locking up the laundry detergent. And it's not just the laundry detergent. It's the ice cream, the beer, the razor blades, haircare products, you name it. She said so many families can't make ends meet right now, I can't imagine thinking that the way to solve the problem is people stealing basic necessities out of desperation is to prosecute them. They think that this is an attack on the poor by the -- that's the solution is to allow people to steal. Instead, what happens is all these businesses wind up shutting down and these neighborhoods become vast wastelands.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: So, if the family needs diapers, at the last minute, that store isn't going to be there any longer. Just like Walgreens was closing stores out in San Francisco.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they blame -- and they blamed Walgreens.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They blamed Walgreens. TARLOV; I definitely --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Criminalization of poverty in a city that has the biggest social safety network in the entire city. I mean, country.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Last -- quick last word?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: So, I was not a Cynthia Nixon backer, but just to push back a little about the January 6 insurrection. There are still congresspeople in the Republican Party who say that they were a bunch of tourists walking through there and then voted to not certify he election --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Nobody in leadership -- nobody in leadership and nobody on TV who is a conservative --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, no one on TV?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- not at this table.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Not Louie Gohmert?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Not at this table. Where is Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez bit mad about her constituents basically being robbed.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The bottom line --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And people are not prosecuted.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The bottom line, I know guys we've got to go. the bottom line is those people are being prosecuted. They are going through the criminal justice system.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: That's what I insist. Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: This is not happening where people get to decide to do this.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Five hundred fifty people are going to be prosecuted by Merrick Garland.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If you have a political will, there is a way. And then people say that there is a two-tier justice system and they're mad. But we're not mad, we're going to keep going. Up next, Republicans slamming the White House and accusing President Biden of going way too soft on China.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (on camera)
utterances.utterance: The White House undergoing pressure to hold China accountable for the COVID pandemic but it doesn't look like that's going to happen.

utterances.speaker: JAKE SULLIVAN, U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER
utterances.utterance: We are not at this point going to issue threats or ultimatums. What we're going to do is continue to rally support in the international community. And if it turns out that China refuses to live up to its international obligations we will have to consider our responses at that point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Dr. Fauci is trying to go on offense claiming once again the attacks on him are attacks on science. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS

utterances.speaker: DISEASES
utterances.utterance: It is essential as a scientist that you evolve your opinion and your recommendations based on the data as it evolves. And that's the reason why I say people who then criticize me about that are actually criticizing science. I put very little weight in the adulation and very little weight into the craziness of condemning me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD (on camera)
utterances.utterance: You're crazy if you condemn him. OK, fair enough. But Lawrence, he reminds, he's got to read the waiting room, right? No one is there to see him anymore, he's like that 1981 issue of highlights that still in Dr. Siegel's office. You know, it served -- it served a purpose a while ago, but now it's just rotting in a corner. It's like the AA -- AARP magazines. Those are (Inaudible) magazines. OK?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Can I defend Fauci without defending Fauci?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course. Scratchy Fauci.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: You should go full attack.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Part of the reason why Fauci is acting this way and we're like, this is strange, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But we put him on a pedestal. I mean, the media, people in public life all went to this guy. So, it's kind of shocking to him that we're reaching this point. I think the most telling thing though, is not just Fauci was a national security advisor saying that we are going to give them the opportunity. China has been given the opportunity. There is no more time for opportunity. How do we move it forward? First of all, we're not going to get the truth when it comes to China anymore. That's not happening.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: We should give up on that front. What we should care about is the people that are in government that had a role in this in the virology lab. That's what we got to get to the bottom of because we don't want that to happen again. Number three, we got to have an actual conversation about putting some pressure on China in the right way. It's an all or nothin gthing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONEs
utterances.utterance: Us getting by and acting like we've got to just pull the Band-Aid off, and we need our allies to do that as well. The problem is that it's going to cost us and no one wants to pay the cost for it. Because you make it in America, there is a premium associated, if you make it in another country --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- there is a premium associated. So, that's where the real conversation is. No one really wants to have that conversation because that's going to cost us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Also, Jessica, to that point, LeBron James can have a discussion about certain things that are happening in America, but because of this cost and this investment, he can't have that discussion in China which makes him look like a filthy hypocrite, Jessica. Why are you so pro- COVID?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, I actually didn't see that twist coming. But now we're here. So, a few weeks ago, we were talking about how could we actually exercise some pressure on China that would be effective. And I -- money is it. Right? That's all that we care about. I mean, we continue to cook push back on the South China Sea, that's something we had going on obviously for years, but it's got to be money and then if it's got to be money it's got to be these private corporations --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: -- that still producers. So, we're looking at Nike, we're looking at Apple, we're looking at the athletes that represent them, et cetera. And I think that that is probably where we're going to end up after we get through this latest round of the WHO report. Now, part of the blessing and the curse of working in coalitions which we are with the rest of the western Democratic world is that you can't step out of line with what Macron is (Inaudible) and Merkel, right, because we want to be united at front here against China beaus it killed all of us. Right. It took 600,000 lives from us. It took, I don't know the exact number but we lost U.K. lives, French, German, everyone. And so, you have to temper your response with what your allies are comfortable with. I mean, that's part of participating in a lot of democracies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's why we shouldn't participate.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should go it alone part.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Yes, that was a beautiful G7 he led there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was. It was. You know, you are such a globalist, Jessica. It makes me sick to my stomach.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: So dirty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dagen. Dagen, what -- I mean, that's a fair point. I mean, what can be done at this point when everything any evidence has been tossed away, and we're, you know, we're involved with the lab as well, so what do we do?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right. And did American money go to basically unleash a virus that killed four million people around the globe? It is on the private corporations. It's not just the companies that make goods in China, it is all of the global multinational space in the United States that viewed China as kind of the golden goose. And they will literally do anything to curry favor with the communist party of China other than maybe send them banana bread and gift certificates to bass pro shops. But you saw what the NBA did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: The NBA backtracked, all of Hollywood does that. They constantly edit films to make sure that they're OK with the communist party. Who was it, John Cena --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Right. On the Fast and the Furious.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: -- backtrack the comments that he made right on Taiwan. Just one quick thing, I think money - China plays on upon our greed, and money, it's not just the G7 that will take and corporate -- private corporations, it really will require dozens of countries. I just want to point really quickly to Imran Khan, the prime minister of Pakistan that we did an interview with a Jonathan Swan in Axios. And he literally said he would not condemn China's treatment of the Uyghurs. And Jonathan Swan said, but it's genocide, it's forced assimilation, it's sterilization. And he said, we have private conversations. China has been one of our greatest friends in difficult times when we were struggling economically. That tells you everything that you need to know.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Money.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They -- somebody who complains about Islamophobia will not condemn China's persecution of Muslims in that country.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just notice that China is the biggest troll in the world. You know what they announced yesterday?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That the Wuhan Institute of Virology is deserving of the Nobel Prize.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it's basically like they are just going to like own it. So why are we waiting like having this conversation. And I think that for Biden, remember he said I'll give you 90 days --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- until the community come back to me. They got to be thinking about what happens on the 91st day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because if it comes back and it is either inconclusive or it lead you to believe that it did start in the lab or, you know, it was an accident or on purpose, then you have to do something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that's the next --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You know what it is, though, Greg, really quickly? It's time. The attention span of the American public. The conversation has shifted to reopening. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And so, we forget about what took place, what got us here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And China was protected for months with the media, the entertainment industry labeling any criticism of China to be racist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Dan Rather. Dan Rather went after Jon Stewart this weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he was basically saying you are attacking the very ideal of science to Jon Stewart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dan rather. Why is he still around? Go away. Up next, if you think the crisis at the border is bad, President Biden is about to open the floodgates.

utterances.speaker: JONES (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. The record smashing the surge of illegal immigration at our southern border. As new video smuggler ferrying at the least 60 migrants into the U.S. And President Biden is about to make it worse. The White House is reporting to set and get rid of a COVID rule called title 42 that let border patrol turned away migrant families due to public health concerns. So, Dana, even if they believe in this, right, is this the right time to do it from a communication standpoint?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe we ought to call the good doctor and see if that is the truth. I mean, does the science tell us? The science tells us that we're not at President Biden's goal of 70 percent vaccinated although he's attempting to get 70 percent at least one shot by July 1st. Getting close in some places now and close than others. If you add a bunch of people who don't have -- do you think they got vaccine on their walk up through Mexico? No, they didn't. So, that's one, that's not going to help. I don't understand why the administration continues to take the easiest things off the table that could help them. One was the remain in Mexico policy. But the other one is this one. Who is going to complain? Like is AOC going to complain that you are denying people to come in because of a public health emergency? Really? So, you have to conclude that may be that they want to do this, I guess. I mean, this is going to swamp the border patrol, they don't have enough resources as it is. But also, remember when Kamala Harris just two weeks she was in Guatemala and she said, do not come here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, this is just another thing of like, well, they don't really mean it. Now we can possibly go if we take our children, they're not going to separate us, we're going to be able to be together and COVID is not a concern anymore.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: So, Jessica, is it the ideology that is leading the way like, just open borders, come all, come all. I mean, at this time it's like, Dana is right. The winds are there and they are refusing to take these winds. Like why remove this?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I love an easy win. That's part of my day job. It's just like, you know, you think crime is bad? Guess what, I think crime is bad too.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I totally get that. And we don't know yet what they're going to do about this law. So, the White House has not said yet. It's actually a CDC decision. So, we'll see what those folks come up with. But there are easy wins here. And frankly, that's how Democrats win elections, especially in border states. There are a lot of Democrats who are elected along the border because they're tough on these issues and compassionate. And it's the same formula --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But you know that -- you know that's change in like, on the border. There are Republicans net are now winning these districts that they didn't win before. I'm not talking about national races, but local races which --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Totally. I mean, look at what happened in Texas.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Correct.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: There's a full shellacking for us. And we thought that we were going to take back the State House and all of that. So, I'm not saying that we are the overwhelming representation, but that people are looking for smart, compassionate solutions to what everybody agrees is a border crisis. And this is something that like Bill Clinton did so well, right? He identified that there are this demographic, national security moms, right, that women are going to go out and are going to vote on this issue. And that's what we need to do again. And we need to come up with smart solutions for those people so that we can be concerned and compassionate at the same time.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Dagen, Joe Biden did it as well. But it seemed to change. What changed?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Nothing is going to change. Their policy is and they won't say it is wide open borders, as you said. The trip down to South of the Border by Vice President Harris, that was just to make it seem like they care about people suffering when they have no intention of making any changes. And when they get rid of -- allow these families to come in and get rid of title 42, here's the messaging that you're going to hear from the White House. Mexico has the second-highest observed case fatality ratio behind Peru. This is this is humanitarian. We need to open our borders and let these people and so they can be vaccinated here in the United States. That would be the argument when they have no -- they're just going to bring as many illegal immigrants into this country as possible. That's been the goal all along.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Dana asked the question, who and why are they taking these sensible solutions off the table? It's due to a concept that I like to call the weaponization of compassion.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's confusing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is that every single --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You talked about it in one show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm going to use it every single day. If you look at like, remain in Mexico, or title 42, or at anything that seems constructive, all you have to do is turn it a certain way and say it's lacking in compassion. It's what Dagen just said about how they will spin this. So, it makes you wonder whether or not they really want a solution or not. The question then is we've been doing this story like three times a week for like four months, right? Is there any persuasion going on between these two camps, right? It seems like it's the never-ending game of rhetorical ping pong. There was one moment of persuasion that leaped beyond this two -- these two idea of prison, of compassion, and process that we seem to be locked into. And we all know we're locked into it and that was the wall that was symbolically and practically perfect persuasion solution. Because you put it up there, it actually blocks traffic and it sends a message at the same time. And the message was seek legal recourse if you want to enter America, you can't do it this way. That was like the best way to do this. But because it was Trump and it was a -- you can't -- every solution now is always going to be, but Trump, right? Remain in Mexico, but Trump. Title 42, but Trump. So now, there's no way again, no way to go but down. There's only one solution and that is like, we can't do anything about it because we're evil.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Just to make one point. So, we have been doing it and actually, if you see the polls that came out Friday, the one issue where Biden is way underwater, like he's like, in the 30s in terms of approval on the border, and that's just because people don't -- if you're being polled as a Democrat, you don't want to say anything negative about him. So, they're also starting to take some -- on some water on crime. What are they announced this week? On Wednesday, Biden and Harris will be at the White House and they're going to do a big thing in the afternoon about how they are addressing crime all across America. But they won't deal with this issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, the one issue that's dragging them down overall and it's -- it is a mystery.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is a mystery, Dana.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, we'll see when it changes which is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Until then, we're going to do these topics every day.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Up next -- up next --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll get into the 20.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Up next, the media and the mayor being slammed after jumping to conclusions on a deadly crash event at a Pride event. We'll talk about that.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: The Democratic mayor of Fort Lauderdale, Florida getting called out for rushing to judgment about a deadly crash at a Pride Parade event this weekend. Instead of just waiting for all the facts to come in, the mayor jumped to this conclusion.

utterances.speaker: DEAN TRANTALIS, MAYOR OF FORT LAUDERDALE, FLORIDA
utterances.utterance: What we saw was a terrorist attack on the LGBT community. This is disgusting. We will not stand for this. This is not going to happen in my city or any city.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Well, the mayor was forced to backtrack after police said it appeared the tragedy was an accident.

utterances.speaker: TRANTALIS
utterances.utterance: I regret the fact that I said it was a terrorist attack because we found out that it was not. But I don't regret my feelings. I don't regret that I fell terrorized.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, please.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Greg, when the mayor said that the venomous twidiots (PH) immediately spread it around and it quickly turned into a homophobic attack that was caused by Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, and I'm not I'm not joking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, wait, that's not true? Oh, there go my talking points. The guy should have just stopped before he said but. Why? I mean, look, we've all been suckered in by our own cognitive biases. When you see a story online, and you just go -- and you go this -- he was -- his cognitive biases led to wishful thinking representing his fact. The mayor did not know that attack was an attack, but he wanted it to be an attack. And that was all -- that was all that mattered. He surrounds himself with news sources that indulges bias. Again, all of us, you know, we can be -- we can say that this happens to us. But the problem in our current climate right now is that social media rewards those who assume the worst intention. Like, imagine if everybody on Twitter imagined the best intentions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There would be no Twitter. It would be gone. There would be no trends. But in order to -- he assumed the very worst, that there's this massive like, I don't know, underground homophobic movement that sending cars into -- you know, meanwhile, the story that's not being discussed, we mentioned in the A block was the Puerto Rican parade in which, you know, a Puerto Rican couple was pulled out by a mob and shot to death. One is -- both was shot, but one is dead. Imagine if these situations were reversed.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes. Why couldn't the mayor just wait?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think he was looking for his 15 minutes of fame.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And maybe it was his instinct, right, in terms of the bias, right? He's like, oh, gosh, here we go. It's going to be a terrorist attack. It's on my watch. I'm the mayor. Instead of like -- basically, he had a reckless disregard for the public's trust. And also, you have to ask if somebody who is an elected official, if their first thought is innocent until proven guilty, if that's not your first thought, then you may be in the wrong line of work as we've heard use the phrase. As we've heard this a couple weeks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And to Greg's point, Jessica, part of the problem is these lies, or false narratives, whatever you want to call them, they live on forever. I will look -- and this is a Glenn Greenwald article that he wrote. The Pulse nightclub shooting happened about five years ago. And that politicians and activists every year talk about that it was an anti-LGBTQ hatred. It was a hate crime. That is not true. And you had U.S. senators have kind of -- Tammy Duckworth, Senator Duckworth was the worst. But that's not what happened. Omar Mateen was motivated by rage over President Obama's bombing campaigns in Syria, Iraq, and Afghanistan, and it's in the 911 call. There are court transcripts about it. But literally, U.S. senators every year are tweeting about it was this hate crime. And he picked it at random and didn't know that it was a gay nightclub. But again, the lie lives on. And it dishonors the victims, frankly.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm not sure. And many of the parents of the Pulse night club shooting victims don't feel that way because it was still a large amount -- there was 49 people that were killed, and they were members of the LGBTQ- plus community.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, but that's not --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: And that means -- it doesn't -- I understand the difference between motivation and results. But the result was 49 people are dead. And I believe a majority -- I don't want to say everyone was a member of this particular community. And the same would be true if someone walked into a Black church and shot it up because they're mad about what's happening down the road --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, but he did it with the intent though.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I understand.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's important. Look, I'm going to just say this. The first thing they teach you in police training or in academy, the hardest thing is notifying the victim, right, because they want to know why and who did it. Even if you have some type of evidence, you're told not to do it because you contain investigation and you just don't know. You can cause other people to be hurt. I guess politicians have the luxury of just putting out misinformation out there. It's hurtful. It's bad for the victims. It's bad for the community. It's bad for the justice system. He should know better.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Can I just add to that? This was the point that I -- that I wanted to make at first about the social media issue. There is so much pressure on people in positions of power to have the answer so quickly. Like, we all sit here waiting for a press -- I know. I just wanted to add to it and agree with someone not from the same party as me that we're screaming, well, I want to make sure that I can talk about this one. Is someone going to come out and give us a press conference? And then, when they say we're still following the facts, were all angry and pissed off about it because we don't have answers about this. And these things are complicated. But for a tiny bit of defense of the mayor, and would have, I think, raised this as an issue, that we are seeing spike in crimes against LGBTQ-plus Americans, most specifically transgender Americans. And if you want to have a conversation about that, I think would been welcomed, but he should never have had a but on that issue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that was a terrible --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That wasn't the platform -- that wasn't the platform to do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because what the -- that's that false argument in that it didn't happen here, but it happens over here. That's the defense that was used for fake hate crimes. Well, OK, this one didn't work out, but you know what's happening over there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jussie Smollett.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But then when you go -- yes, the Smollett thing was like, that may not be true but it's true somewhere else. You can't do that because it --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It muddies the water.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Right. And also, senators are using the Pulse nightclub shooting year after year with a false narrative for their own political game. There's nothing more disgusting than that. "THE FASTEST" is up next.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. It's time for "THE FASTEST." First up, passengers are furious after being stranded all over the country. That's because American Airlines canceled more than 300 flights this weekend thanks to staffing and maintenance issues. And the problem could get worse this summer because of a pilot shortage. Dagen, I'm going to go over to you. You know the most about what's happening here.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Because I'm a loser and a nerd and I just cram facts into my head. Part of the problem is that they -- the furloughed pilots need retraining. But American's slogan should be, making you hate us even more than you already do. Because all these airlines got bailed out by U.S. taxpayers tens of billions of dollars. And guess what, it was like six figures per employee and they can't get their act together, screwing us over at every term. Fly Delta.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: You're an American Airlines frequent flyer and a bad -- a mad one at that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Sometimes, you know, you're forced -- I prefer Delta, but sometimes you're forced to take American just because of travel. You need to go do a report real quick. So, I'm forced to take America. Every single time there's a problem, because there's so much in competence. I don't even think they treat their workers fairly as well. So, yes, it serve them right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All I can think of right now is Americans' corporate PR. Oh, my gosh, we're about to get crushed.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's happened.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the other issues is that they'll say they'll cancel your flight, but that we'll rebook you on Sunday. But that means I miss the wedding, and also I have childcare issues or dog care issues or something. It's a whole cascading effect. Then when you call customer service, it's like, oh, there's a five-hour-20-minute wait.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: And we'll call you back, but we'll only do it once. And if you don't pick up, then that's the end of that. Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, since Jesse Watters is not here, I am going to be the Jesse Watters of this table and defend American Airlines because I want to be upgraded and I want to be treated as special as I am. And I'm going to say it's very -- we're all going through very difficult times. A lot of these companies -- this is the first time for a pandemic. They don't know what to do. And they certainly don't want to put pilots up there that aren't properly trained. So, for us to say to American Airlines, please fly with less competent pilots, and then if we die, we're going to sue the --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You're only saying that because you fly private.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that's not true. I have not flown private in years. I don't like private. As Bernie Sanders would say, the planes were too bumpy or too bumpy. That's what he said.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's true. It makes you deaf too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Well, I'll have to stop flying private then. "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, let's do this. Greg's what Dana's dreams look like part two. All right, here it is. This is what Dana's dreams look like part two. She doesn't know where she is. It's mysterious. And then --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh boy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here come the dogs. Here come the dogs. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's so fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is it really fun? I had the craziest dreams this weekend. I don't know if it's the melatonin. I only take three milligrams every other day. My dreams are so insanely vivid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you remember them?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: God, to a tee. Like, I always move back to my hometown and take a job in my hometown.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In San Mateo?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: In San Mateo. And I need a car to get around but I don't have one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And is (INAUDIBLE) from the -- formerly from the Patriots there. Tom Brady?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tom Brady, yes. He ends -- we end up becoming next-door neighbors. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So sweet. And then you do a sitcom together?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: God, it's amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is amazing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a lovely dream. I wanted to do a little weekend shout-out to friends of ours, the Fritz's. This is Greg's favorite course.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course, it's the Fritz's.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's the Fritz's, the Fritz family.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I love them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Lawrence loves them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hope you have a lot of pictures.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Here we go. This is Caroline and she's there with Jasper and Ella and Stella. Those are the mermaids, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What did the Fritz have on you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then we have Collin. Check him out. This is the new baby. He's the cute one. You got Hudson, very patriotic young man, Hudson. Then you got Ry-Ry, this is Ryan. He is being held up in the air by his dad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not safe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then this little one is Layton. There she is, Layton and Jasper.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: That's a lot of babies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they really have welcomed us into their home and we appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Better Layton than never.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Dagen.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: So, a small dog causing a lot of chaos in the streets of Lima, Peru. This perfectly -- so, this dog is named Moochie. They were chasing her all around in the street. Drivers, delivery workers, neighbors trying to catch her. She -- they even shut down part of the road. They never could get her. She eventually, because she's smarter than those humans, ran into a veterinary clinic where she was captured and then reunited with their owners. But I call this my friends trying to get me out of the bar and get me home. That's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll keep that in mind next time.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That was me this weekend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All right, so if the final round of the U.S. Open was last night, and golfer Louis Oosthuizen or whatever is his name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's not how you pronounce it, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I wasn't going to do that. He was trying to force a plow against Jon Rahm. Now, check this out. He was setting up this put on the 17th hole, which was -- would have kept him one stroke behind Rahm. He made the shot, but a tense moment wound up becoming a cliffhanger as some viewers of Iowa -- take a look at this. Right when the ball is rolling toward the whole, the local NBC station broke in with a severe weather warning. So, he wound up missing the crucial putt. And a chunk of Iowa golf fans were set out for maybe the most pivotal shot of the year.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It reminds me and my sister and I in Parker, Colorado where we were growing up. We recorded Grease on a VCR tape. And at the -- in the middle of one of the coolest songs, every time we played it, there was a tornado warning.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Oh, man.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Can you imagine? That would be (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They ruined the whole experience for you, didn't they?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My mom didn't buy us the movie. We had to get it off the TV.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It was during -- she's a real wagon.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: Danny Zuko for life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: All right, it was a big weekend for the Olympic trials. And nobody attracted more attention and praise than American sprinter Sha'Carri Richardson. The former LSU sprinter and Dallas Texas native --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: --- bolted past the competition in 100-meter sprint and was far enough ahead that she pointed at the clock with 30 meters left to go. As if becoming America's fastest woman wasn't enough of an accomplishment, Richardson revealed that she had lost her mother just a week before.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: She said, my family's kept me grounded. This year has been crazy for me going from just last week losing my biological mother and I'm still here. Well, she's definitely still here. We can't wait to cheer you on in the Olympics, Sha'Carri.Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: She's the boss.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I can't wait to watch her.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.utterance: She's amazing, and her hair makeup, the nails.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The whole thing.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's how we do it in Dallas, Texas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
